reviewText: I just picked this up today at Walmart for $9. I just happened to be walking by and spotted all four of the latest releases from Dragon Dynasty. It made my day to pick this up and I plan on picking up a couple more of the new releases tomorrow.The DVD transfer looks ok, but nothing extraordiary. The color looks good but the focus can be off at times.The posterization seems minimal and I didn't notice any blocking or any general blurriness of the image that isn't on par with other recent DD Shaw Brothers releases. I just use the TV speakers so I can't offer any useful feedback on the audio.The film itself is 5-stars, no question it's a classic. It introduced us to the infamous Pai Mei, one of the great characters not only in the history of Kung-Fu but of cinema in general. My question is why no extras??? I suppose I should come to expect this with DD. Don't get me wrong, I love the fact that DD is releasing this at all. But honestly, one or two five-minute extras would be nice.Also, why are these not simultaneously being released on blu-ray? I'm not sure what kind of investment has to be made to create a blu-ray quality release but if any film deserves it it's this one. Overall it's definitely worth the $9 at your local walmart if you don't want to wait until the 16th to get it via Amazon. And if you already ordered it and have to wait, I'm sorry...
summary: Great movie! No extras, as usual...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Nice... one of Liu Chia-Liang's best movies.  Saw his cameo in there at Pai Mei's temple.  Wow, Pai Mei, now I know why he's such a legendary villain, loved his character, but then again he was played by the always reliable Lo Lieh, who makes such a great villain, seen a couple dozen of his movies.  I enjoyed the serious vibe most of the movie had.  Not always a big fan of Liu Chia-Liang's humor, but the bride with super strong legs, who demanded her husband part them on his own before he could have her... ok that was hilarious.

reviewText: Run Run Shaw top favorite right here.  I loved this movie and had to have it in my colleciton.  I would most definetly recommend this to others who love martial arts.

reviewText: The print of this film is very good, transfer to DVD medium okay, letterbox is fine, no loss of image.  Subtitles are well placed.  The kung-fu is very well done, but the plot is long and drawn out, beside that, this is a very good film to watch and enjoy.E.V.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Lau Kar-Leung (Liu Chia-Liang), in 1977, directed his third film for the Shaws.  As usual he choreographed as well as directed.  Look close for his cameo too; the second time Hung Hsi-Kuan (holding a staff) raids Pai Mei's place, Lau sifu is the minion with the three-sectioned-staff during the fight on the steps.  Despite not making as many movies as Chang Cheh during the year (and getting crap from Run Run Shaw & Mona Fong for it) he hits another winner out of the ballpark.  Hey, it's quality not quantity.  Besides, Chang prefered to be studio-bound, Lau sifu liked to shoot outdoors more, and that takes a bit longer.In any case, the movie is terrific.  Lo Lieh in his best iconic portrayal of Priest Pai Mei & Chen Kuan-Tai playing Hung Hsi-Kuan (I think this was his third time in the role of Hung; third time's the charm).  Great performances by Lily Li, Wong Yu, Chiang Tao, and watch out for Gordon Liu's opening fight where he sacrifices himself.  Awesome fu; showcasing Fu Jow Pai (Tiger Claw style) & it gives an explanation on the origin of Hung Gar (Tiger/Crane style).Now for the DVD, Dragon Dynasty did a great job with the movie itself; remastered widescreen picture.  It's shown in the original Mandarin language (as well as a decent English dub), good subtitles (not dubtitles).  However, what is with that stupid box art.  Even worse than the cover, what's up with the picture of Lo Lieh in a freakin' samurai outfit on the back?  What genius was behind that marketing ploy?  Here's the deal, ignore the lame box art, but purchase the DVD if you're a Shaw/Lau sifu fan.  It's a great film, that's my opinion and I'm sticking with it.

reviewText: This Film Was The Bomb Really Enjoyed It Alot, Exspecially All The Fighting Choreography. Dragon Dynasty Rules They Are The Best Right Up There With All The Shaw Brother Films. Dragon Dynasty Keep Doing Your Thing Recommend Any Of These Films For The Martial Arts Fan In You!!!! Thanks ForThe Prompted Service Will Be Buying More In The Future Sincerly Mr. Stone
